A strong focal point for centaurs is to be encouraged to explore and discover what they enjoy over the course of their long lifespan.

This has a very dramatic effect on relationships. A pairing of centaurs may last a month or can last a year. Friendships can drift apart just as quickly as they can be seemingly brought together. An important philosophy: passion can be extinguished just as quickly as it can be ignited. Of course, if any kind of relationship didn't end terribly, both parties know it is of no offense to them personally—they just feel each other being drawn elsewhere.

entries.name: Subraces
entries: Most centaurs are Ansalonites, the most common and populous variety of centaur. There are three rarer types that do not take like their other kin, however. Below is information on three rarer subtypes of centaur, characterized usually by the stark constrasts to Ansalonites.

entries.name: Crystalmir
entries: Crystalmir centaurs are shy and reclusive, and have not spread as widely as their close cousins, the Ansalonites. Crystalmirs are usually blonde or light brown in colour, with black or chestnut highlights; a few herds are sloid black or white. Crystalmirs seldom cooperate with other intelligent races, refusing to speak with strangers until they are completely convinced that they mean the herd no harm.

entries.name: Endscapes
entries: Endscapes are the most savage breed of centaurs, fond of strong wine and inebriation. They often making drunken raids on human villages, and thrill to vandalise buildings, terrorise humans, steal food and tools, and kidnap human women (who fascinate Endscape males). These lawless, merciless centaurs are not well-loved by other races.

entries.name: Wendles
entries: Resembling young Ansalonites, Wendles average only four to five feet in height, but are distinguished by their golden eyes and stubby tails. Wendles are the intellectuals among centaur breeds, and are interested in philosophy, history, and other scholastic pursuits. Wendles can be a good source of information, once they have been convinced to cooperate; they are very argumentative creatures, and quite stubborn.

entries.name: Survivor.
entries: You have proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Animal Handling, Medicine, Nature, or Survival.

entries.name: Swift Rider.
entries: You can use the Dash action as a bonus action.

entries.name: Charge.
entries: If you move at least 30 feet straight toward a target and then hit it with a melee weapon attack on the same turn, you can immediately follow that attack with a bonus action, making one attack against the target with your hooves.

entries.name: Endscape Weapon Training.
entries: You have proficiency with the shortbow, light crossbow, scimitar, and net.

entries.name: Spell Affinity.
entries: One of your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma scores increase by 1, your choice. Additionally, if you chose Intelligence, you can choose one cantrip from the wizard spell list, using Intelligence as your spellcasting ability modifier; if you chose Wisdom, you can choose one cantrip from the druid spell list, using Wisdom as your spellcasting ability modifier; if you chose Charisma, you can choose one cantrip from the sorcerer spell list, using Charisma as your spellcasting ability modifier.

entries.name: Quick Thinking.
entries: You can take the Search or Disengage action as a bonus action.

entries.name: Extra Language.
entries: You learn any additional language of your choosing.

entries.name: Age
entries: Minotaurs mature at about 17, and can live to be almost 200 years old.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Minotaurs tend toward lawful and neutral alignments, but rarely chaos. Like humans, the best and the worst are found among them.

entries.name: Size
entries: Minotaurs have variable sizing, standing anywhere between 6 to almost 9 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Hybrid Nature.
entries: You have two creature types: humanoid and monstrosity. You can be affected by a game effect if it works on either of your creature types.

entries.name: Darkvision.
entries: Due to your many nights on the sea and your monstrous ancestry, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Minotaur Armor Training.
entries: You gain proficiency with light and medium armor.

entries.name: Mariner.
entries: While you aren't wearing heavy armor or using a shield, you can use your bonus action to gain either a swim speed or climbing speed of 40 feet until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Seabound Soul.
entries: You gain proficiency with vehicles (water) and navigator's tools, your choice.

entries.name: Languages.
entries: You know Common and Tallspeak (Giant).

Another side effect of Chaos' calamity, minotaurs live in a codified, honor-bound society whether the strongest rule and call the shots, both in the arenas and in daily life. They revere and admire three traits in particular: strength, cunning, and intellect. Notable sea reavers and ship builders, minotaurs of Krynn count as some of the most capable and ferocious in all the land.

Most minotaurs of past centuries often leaned heavily into the belief that the weak should perish under the strong. Uowever, under the Sumaparr Reign which started the Age of Mortals began, some are becoming more soft spoken of those that cannot help themselves. As a result, minotaurs lean as  heavily into other alignments as their human half- counterparts.

entries.name: Rulers by Might, not Right
entries: Minotaur society is built on the principle that might makes right, and that considerations of justice come second to a trial by combat. The minotaurs of Minos are led by an emperor, served by a council of eight minotaurs called the Supreme Circle. All posts within the government, including the emperor's throne, are won by the strongest and cleverest minotaurs, as proved by combat in the Circle.

The Circus is one of the fastest means by which a minotaur can rise in society. It is a grand, triannual display display of single combat in which minotaurs battle each other for supremacy. Minotaur youth often fight each other in the Circus as to prove themselves and make the passage from child to adult. While all of these fights used to be to the death, fights now are required to be nonlethal, letting the loser bear the shame of their defeat.
For Krynnish minotaurs, the Circus is one reason why they feel themselves a superior race—battle, combat, and strife help weed out the weak and sharpen the senses of the strong.

entries.name: Honor in Battle and Life
entries: A victory is a proud badge to be worn and flaunted. A defeat is a stain that only death can full cleanse someone of: that is to be a minotaur of Krynn. Even outside of the field of war, these creatures are one of their word, never straying from a promise. They remain fiercely loyal to their friends and clan. If a minotaur does strike up a friendship of their own volition, it is typically with other creatures that display that minotaur's virtues, especially a love for battle. Once someone has proven their worth to a minotaur, they have made a lifelong friend.

entries.name: Islands and Clans
entries: The land of Minos, country of minotaurs, takes after an almost mycenaean Greek culture of islandic seafarers. Their populace is split among two major areas: Kothas, the capital of Minos, and Mithas, the center for training and learning. Various other towns and ports make up the smaller islands in the Minos Archipelago.

For minotaurs, their island of dwelling and birth is just as significant as the clan they represent. People from lands controlled by Mithas have the prefix "es-" before their clan name; those under the sway of Kothas use "de-"; finally, residents of the Minos Islands under neither use "ol-".

entries.name: Kothas
entries: Minotaurs hailing from Kothas take great pride in the Emperor and the arena in which they  hold the Circus. The people of Kothas remain stead- fast and strong, going to great lengths to do what they  can to help any war effort. Such things, they believe, show strength, dedication, and a strong sense of community, even between clans. The people of Kothas are especially inclined towards strength.

entries.name: Mithas
entries: The heart of scholarly learning and teaching, Mithas is the mage and warrior's heart of the Minos Archipelago. Many creatures from nonrival nations often find themselves arriving here to train and practice with the peers of those who take intelligence in great stride. Those of Mithas are especially smart and bright.

entries.name: Minos Islands
entries: The scattered islands around the Blood Sea are dangerous, but profitable. Most of these colonies are cohabitated by other races, yet remain strictly under the rule of minotaurs. They remain as diverse as other human settlements.

entries.name: Cordial Introductions
entries: In Minos, there is a great deal of importance around your family and how you grew up. Minotaurs often pride themselves on their history and lineage, so much so that they place it before themselves. Minotaurs from distinguished clans and families often introduce themselves by their last name—their clan name and place of birth—when making acquainted with strangers. It can be considered a strong faux pas to refer to a minotaur by their first name if they haven't given permission to be called otherwise.

Where a creature was born and how powerful their clan is influences how quickly they may change their inclination for how they wish to be called by their friends and close ones. Those from Kothas are more likely to be honor bound and present themselves by their clan, only really loosening up after tight-knit bonds are formed, or between lovers. Minotaurs from Mithas or the various Minos islands are more relaxed, usually letting most friends refer to them by their first name. Those of noble birth or from larger, more influential clans often wait longer to administer this privilege to other creatures.

entries.name: Horns.
entries: Your horns are natural melee weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal piercing damage equal to {@dice {@dice {@dice 1d6}}} + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Martial Maneuvering.
entries: You have advantage on any roll to avoid being grappled.

entries.name: Conquerer's Knowledge.
entries: Knowledge. You have proficiency in the History and Religion skills.

entries.name: Seafarer's Footing.
entries: You have advantage on any roll to avoid being knocked prone.

entries.name: Age
entries: As humanoids related to the giants, Half Ogres can have long lifespans if they don’t grow up in a war torn lifestyle. A Half Ogre reaches adulthood around 20, and the oldest of them can live for 500 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Apparently Crag doesn't care, so whatever tf you want I suppose.

entries.name: Size
entries: You stand around 8ft tall and weigh around 450lbs. Your Size is Large.

entries.name: Speed
entries: From your larger legs compared to that of a normal person, your base movement is 35ft

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Gluttonous Diet
entries: From such variety typically found in the Ogre and Half Ogre diet, you have resistance to poison damage and advantage on saves against being poisoned.

entries.name: Brutish Make
entries: You gain Proficiency in Athletics.

entries.name: Giantkin
entries: You have two creature types, Humanoid and Giant.

entries.name: Temper
entries: From your heritage, you tend to have a short fuse that leads to violence, which often blows when provoked. As a reaction to taking damage, you can enter an enraged state similar to that of a barbarian's rage. While in this state, you gain a +1 to melee attack rolls and to melee damage rolls for 1 minute. You then cannot use this ability again until you complete a short or long rest. At 11th level, the damage from this ability increases to +2. At 17th level, this damage increases to +3.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can speak and read Common and Giant.
